Award.AwardTitle: Probing Energy Loss in the Quark Gluon Plasma with Direct Photon Correlations
Award.AbstractNarration:
A hot, dense state of matter known as the Quark Gluon Plasma (QGP) is produced in high-energy collisions of nuclei at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) and reproduces the early stages of the universe. Exploring the QGP enhances our understanding of the nuclear force and sheds light on the workings of the young universe. The properties of the QGP are studied by measuring the characteristics of the particles produced in the collisions using detectors that are at large and complex experiments like PHENIX. This award will support a project that uses data collected by PHENIX to investigate how some of the signals of particles coming out of the collisions are correlated with each other. In addition to the analysis of PHENIX data, this project will work on the instrumentation development and testing of detector components for an upgrade planned for the PHENIX detector called sPHENIX. This detector that will make precise measurements that will enhance further our understanding of the inner workings of the QGP.

This project will measure direct photon-hadron correlations in heavy ion collisions recorded by PHENIX. Photon-hadron correlations have long been considered a "golden channel" for studying jets in the QGP. Since the photon does not interact via the strong force, it escapes the QGP unmodified and therefore can be used to estimate the initial momentum of the opposing jet. Analyzing the newer larger PHENIX datasets will enable more differential measurements than previously achieved, which will give access to the transport coefficients of the QGP. In addition to the PHENIX analysis, an effort is provided for developing and testing the hadronic calorimeter for sPHENIX where photon-jet correlations will be accessible in addition to other jet substructure observables. Such measurements are crucial for developing a complete understanding of the QGP and the strong force.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) collides gold ions at high energy to produce a phase of nuclear matter known as the quark-gluon plasma (QGP) in which quarks and gluons that are normally confined within hadrons such as the proton, can behave as free particles. Some high momentum particles will traverse and lose energy in the QGP before they eventually fragment into a collimated spray of particles known as jets. Jet quenching, which was first observed via modification to particle production in heavy ion collisions relative to proton-proton collisions, is one of the major discoveries from the early days of RHIC. However, more precise jet measurements are crucial to improving models, which describe energy loss properties in the QGP and ultimately improve our understanding of the nuclear strong force. One way of measuring jets is using two particle correlations in which the angular distribution of associated particles is measured relative to a trigger particle. Triggering on a direct photon gives access to the initial jet energy. However, direct photon measurements are challenging due to the large contribution of decay photons from neutral pion decays. Neutral pions can also be used as a trigger particle to provide insight to the jets with higher statistics. This project supported graduate students measuring both direct photon and neutral pion triggered correlations to probe how the energy lost in the QGP is redistributed. Because of this award, results from data collected by PHENIX in 2010 and 2011 are being prepared for publication while work on calibrations for later large data sets collected in 2014 and 2016 are also being finalized.

 

In parallel, students worked on testing detector components for the sPHENIX project. sPHENIX, designed specifically to measure jets, is an upgrade to PHENIX and is scheduled to start taking data in 2023.  The largest sPHENIX subsystem is the hadronic calorimeter (HCal), which is crucial for accurately measuring the energy of the jets. The HCal is comprised of scintillator tiles sandwiched between steel plates. The light produced in the scintillator tiles is directed to a silicon photomultiplier (SiPM) by a wavelength shifting fiber. The PI served as an advisor for graduate and undergraduate students working on designing a test stand for the tiles, testing the tiles and performing aging studies on the tiles. Through their involvement in this project, students developed useful hardware and coding skills. The students involved in this project reflect the diverse student body at Georgia State University (GSU). This along with the PI?s outreach activities, which includes elementary, middle and high school students, and her role as advisor to the GSU Women in Physics student organization aim toward increasing the number of underrepresented minorities in STEM. The radiation and cosmic ray station developed by the PI for Discovery Day during the Atlanta Science Festival serves to educate the general public about nuclear physics.
